27-0 At End Of Half

The Black and Blue scored one
more touchdown in the first half as
a result of several gains around the
ends by Kelly, McClean and Beeler.
After bringing the ball to the sixyard line, McClean passed to Kelly
who was waiting in the end zone
to score the last goal of the first
half. McClean added the point
again and the score stood Hopkins
27, Loyola 0, at the half.
No scoring took place in the third
period, but in the final quarter
Church Yearley nabbed a Loyola
fumble on a fake-punt formation
and gave Hopkins another scoring
opportunity on the Greyhounds' 16yard line. Two rushes and a pass
brought the Black and Blue to the

These Pacifists
Scarcely any news source or comment
today neglects to mention the imminence
of another world war. Papers and magazines, public orators and parlor conversationalists speak forebodngly about
European saber-rattling, Hitlerite swashbuckling, war clouds in the East. Incredible as it may seem, there are actually
those who look forward to war, and some,
more moral, are simply resigned to it as
an impending reality.
The situation affords at the same time
a happy hunting ground and a cause for
sorrow among our friends the pacifists.
It's a most opportune time to leap into
the middle of things and begin to shout
about brotherly love and don't-fightunder-any-circumstances, and yet the
cause of international fraternalism is in
a fairer way to subversion than it's been
in twenty years. People, somehow, did
not learn anything from the holacost of

whole matter of amoebas, and was
ready. As everyone knows, Dr.
Cowles has written a book entitled
"A Biological Survey of the Off
Shore Waters in the Chesapeake
Bay," which was published in 1930.
The work of compiling such a great
project occupied about ten years,
three of which were spent in actual survey, and the rest of the time
in the study of his findings. Needless to say, Dr. Cowles is the acknowledged authority on the matter.
The Chesapeake seems to have a
wonderful fascination for him, for
at this very moment he is working
with Dr. Brambel, preparing for a
survey of the distribution of animal and plant life in the Bay. They

the leading role? (You ought to hear
him vociferate on occasion, usually
when this copy is turned in.)

International News Service tells
us that co-eds in Soviet Russia are
majoring in shoe making and minoring in carpet weaving so that they
may prepare for their industrial
country.

At Harco, Illinois, the construction of a new school building makes
it necessary for the upper classes to
hold their classes in the Red Onion
dance hall.

The Pitt News comes forth with
the sad tale of two dead panther
cubs. It seems that the first one,
in his official capacity as mascot of
the football team, was deemed
worthy enough to be photographed.
However, he died from the shock!
Panther/ No. 2 did not survive him
long, so the team had to borrow a
cub before they could celebrate.

Southern California had its twoyear winning streak shattered Saturday when held to a tie by Oregon
State. Michigan and Princeton
loomed big with impressive victories
over Ohio State and Columbia, respectively. Duke and Alabama lead
in the South.

Byron Price, chief of the Washington bureau of the Associated
Press, will speak at the opening
meeting of the two-day session here,
Friday, November 17, at 1 :30 P. M.
He and Watson Davis are alreadY
members of Pi Delta Epsilon, it
was learned.
John E. Allen, of New York, edi'
tor of Linotype News, will come to
Baltimore from Washington and
Lee University, where he will address the journalism department
there, November 17, to- speak here
on the morning of November 18 on
"Newspaper Make-Up," on which
subject he is a recognized authoritY.
Students and faculty members at
the Hopkins are invited to attend
the I. N. A. banquet.

Initiating its third season at the
Hopkins, the Chess Club will hold
a reorganization meeting at 12:20
tomorrow in the library of Levering Hall. All students who are interested are urged to attend.
Albert Potts, one of the charter
members , of the group, has announced that a match with the University of Virginia is pending. Last
year the team experienced a very
successful season.

By STANLEY BLUMBERG

REGARDLESS of any other
startling feats Hopkins may perform during the balance of the season (and we believe that the Van
Or-men have plenty of tricks left
in the old bag) their rout of Loyola
last Friday night will be to us the
high-water mark of the season, because:
It proved to the spectator that
the Jays really have something.
It proved to the team that its confidence in itself was justified.
It proved to Coach Van Orman
that Henry Beeler is ready and fit
to step into the star ball carrier's
Shoes vacated by Pete Reynolds.
And it disproved the commonly
accepted belief that the only way to
arouse the enthusiasm of a Hopkins crowd at a football game is to
Pass out free cigarettes, or conduct
a medical operation in midfield.

and president of the I. N. A.,

to various universities.

more touchdown in the first half as
a result of several gains around the
ends by Kelly, McClean and Beeler.

to score the last goal of the first
half. McClean added the point
again and the score stood Hopkins
27, Loyola 0, at the half.

These Pacifists
Scarcely any news source or comment
today neglects to mention the imminence
of another world war. Papers and magazines, public orators and parlor conversationalists speak forebodngly about
European saber-rattling, Hitlerite swashbuckling, war clouds in the East. Incredible as it may seem, there are actually
those who look forward to war, and some,
more moral, are simply resigned to it as
an impending reality.
The situation affords at the same time
a happy hunting ground and a cause for
sorrow among our friends the pacifists.
It's a most opportune time to leap into
the middle of things and begin to shout
about brotherly love and don't-fightunder-any-circumstances, and yet the
cause of international fraternalism is in
a fairer way to subversion than it's been
in twenty years. People, somehow, did
not learn anything from the holacost of

whole matter of amoebas, and was
ready. As everyone knows, Dr.
Cowles has written a book entitled
"A Biological Survey of the Off
Shore Waters in the Chesapeake
Bay," which was published in 1930.
The work of compiling such a great
project occupied about ten years,
three of which were spent in actual survey, and the rest of the time
in the study of his findings. Needless to say, Dr. Cowles is the acknowledged authority on the matter.
The Chesapeake seems to have a
wonderful fascination for him, for
at this very moment he is working
with Dr. Brambel, preparing for a
survey of the distribution of animal and plant life in the Bay. They

the Barn the other night, if one can

And if the play is to be "Front

the leading role? (You ought to hear
him vociferate on occasion, usually
when this copy is turned in.)

International News Service tells
us that co-eds in Soviet Russia are
majoring in shoe making and minoring in carpet weaving so that they
may prepare for their industrial
country.

At Harco, Illinois, the construction of a new school building makes
it necessary for the upper classes to
hold their classes in the Red Onion
dance hall.

The Pitt News comes forth with
the sad tale of two dead panther
cubs. It seems that the first one,
in his official capacity as mascot of
the football team, was deemed
worthy enough to be photographed.
However, he died from the shock!
Panther/ No. 2 did not survive him
long, so the team had to borrow a
cub before they could celebrate.

Southern California had its twoyear winning streak shattered Saturday when held to a tie by Oregon
State. Michigan and Princeton
loomed big with impressive victories
over Ohio State and Columbia, respectively. Duke and Alabama lead
in the South.

Byron Price, chief of the Washington bureau of the Associated
Press, will speak at the opening
meeting of the two-day session here,
Friday, November 17, at 1 :30 P. M.
He and Watson Davis are alreadY
members of Pi Delta Epsilon, it
was learned.
John E. Allen, of New York, edi'
tor of Linotype News, will come to
Baltimore from Washington and
Lee University, where he will address the journalism department
there, November 17, to- speak here
on the morning of November 18 on
"Newspaper Make-Up," on which
subject he is a recognized authoritY.
Students and faculty members at
the Hopkins are invited to attend
the I. N. A. banquet.

Initiating its third season at the
Hopkins, the Chess Club will hold
a reorganization meeting at 12:20
tomorrow in the library of Levering Hall. All students who are interested are urged to attend.
Albert Potts, one of the charter
members , of the group, has announced that a match with the University of Virginia is pending. Last
year the team experienced a very
successful season.

By STANLEY BLUMBERG

REGARDLESS of any other
startling feats Hopkins may perform during the balance of the season (and we believe that the Van
Or-men have plenty of tricks left
in the old bag) their rout of Loyola
last Friday night will be to us the
high-water mark of the season, because:
It proved to the spectator that
the Jays really have something.
It proved to the team that its confidence in itself was justified.
It proved to Coach Van Orman
that Henry Beeler is ready and fit
to step into the star ball carrier's
Shoes vacated by Pete Reynolds.
And it disproved the commonly
accepted belief that the only way to
arouse the enthusiasm of a Hopkins crowd at a football game is to
Pass out free cigarettes, or conduct
a medical operation in midfield.
